9/10/19, 4:50 PM - Caleb: Basically it's a startup that developed an algorithm which is a live diagnostic tool for calls with 911 dispatchers

9/12/19, 10:18 PM - Caleb: I read about it in this book called "Being Mortal"
9/12/19, 10:19 PM - Caleb: But anyway, it's basically that when looking back and remembering how we feel about something, we'll remember it most by how we felt from whatever the most intense moment was up until the end
9/12/19, 10:20 PM - Caleb: So if you had a really shitty morning, then a great thing happens and you just kind of coast, you'll remember it as a good day

12/5/19, 10:17 PM - Marianna: Yeah it‚Äôs supposed to be a huge umbrella
12/5/19, 10:17 PM - Marianna: I‚Äôm trying to align dna from all vertebrates to see the evolution tree

12/5/19, 10:27 PM - Caleb: Woah
12/5/19, 10:27 PM - Caleb: That's absolutely wild
12/5/19, 10:27 PM - Caleb: Okay so basically
12/5/19, 10:27 PM - Caleb: You know how cancer starts, right?
12/5/19, 10:27 PM - Caleb: Mutations
12/5/19, 10:28 PM - Caleb: Well if you have more cells, it means that there's a higher chance one of them mutates and you get cancer
12/5/19, 10:29 PM - Caleb: So why do humans get cancer SO MUCH more frequently than whales?
12/5/19, 10:30 PM - Caleb: Or mice
12/5/19, 10:31 PM - Caleb: "A man has 1000 times as many cells as a mouse and we usually live at least 30 times as long as mice. Exposure of two similar organisms to risk of carcinoma, one for 30 times as long as the other, would give 30^4 or 30^6 times the risk of carcinoma induction per epithelial cell. However, it seems that, in the wild, the probabilities of carcinoma induction in mice and in men are not vastly different. Are our stem cells really, then, a billion or a trillion times more "cancerproof" than murine stem cells? This is biologically pretty implausible; if human DNA is no more resistant to mutagenesis in vitro than mouse DNA, why don't we all die of multiple carcinomas at an early age?"
12/5/19, 10:36 PM - Marianna: Woah
12/5/19, 10:36 PM - Marianna: That‚Äôs cool
12/5/19, 10:36 PM - Marianna: I think I understand
12/5/19, 10:37 PM - Marianna: I feel like I‚Äôve never really thought of animals getting cancer
12/5/19, 10:37 PM - Marianna: Like I know dogs do but I‚Äôve never thought about whales getting cancer
12/5/19, 10:40 PM - Caleb: Yeah
12/5/19, 10:40 PM - Caleb: It's wild
12/5/19, 10:41 PM - Caleb: You might already know this because of bio or compbio, but basically DNA has methods of "spellchecking" itself
12/5/19, 10:41 PM - Caleb: And one of the reasons cancer happens is because there's a mutation in the very spell checker
12/5/19, 10:42 PM - Caleb: And there's TONS of theories about these spell checkers and all sorts of other reasons
12/5/19, 10:42 PM - Caleb: Genetics are wild
12/5/19, 10:44 PM - Marianna: Mmb Or mbb or soemthing
